title: Robert Louis Stevenson
author: Black, Margaret Moyes
snippet: Thecentre of things was in those grand grey houses from Heriot Row upwardsto Charlotte Square, westwards to Randolph Cliff and a little way overthe Dean Bridge. Drumsheugh Gardens was an innovation. The terraces,Royal, Regent, and Carlton, that 'west end of the east,' were stillfashionable, and few people had, as yet, migrated southwards to

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: 388 OLD DIARIES [1900the second son, " Willie," a tall youth, but short comparedto his colossally tall sisters. I went into Edinburgh one day to see my old friendCharles Chambers ; he is now married, and lives in a handsome house in Drumsheugh Gardens ; his country house isat Dunkeld. How these northern publishers do flourish !On returning from Edinburgh, I found at Newbythfresh guests ; these were Mr and Mrs Berkeley, and hersister, Miss Wilmont.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: Besides turning the key, he dragged a table across against the door, and against the table he tilted a chair, so that a push would make it go over. Then he undressed, and, after turning down the light, looked out quietly to see whether anyone haunted the House of Resi dence, as he had haunted Drumsheugh Gardens. But the white streets were quiet and empty.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: LORD INCH left the Parliament House for the last time that night, carried thence to Drumsheugh Gardens in a hearse that bore a snowy pall before it reached his door. For the snow that had threatened in the morning had fallen all through the afternoon, and still drifted down, making all the streets white and silent for his last home-coming.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: For another thing, the young fellow had been very much sobered by a chat with Maitland, who, meeting him in Drumsheugh Gardens one day, had invited him in, and talked gravely of Lord Inch s condition.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: Ix a house not far from No. 45 Drumsheugh Gardens, that confirmed bachelor and well-known physician, Dr. Maitland, was sitting down to his dinner the same evening, when his man handed him a note from Xo. 45.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: The quiet repose of Drumsheugh Gardens, or the sight of these preparations for habitation, interested him so much that the following morning, at about half-past ten, Mr. Peters chose to smoke a cigar in that direction again. He had scarcely turned in at the eastern end, when he saw a

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Lieutenant Prescott divided his time betweenDrumsheugh Gardens and Leith Walk; like aUother interested parties, taking it for granted thathis Irish friend and the Heiress were " bookedthrough," as he termed it. The scales of misconception,however, dropped from his eyes a few evenings afterMyrtle's return.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Thae Gordons hae been the blessin' tae MistressBlain, I can teU ye, for afore she got them, she waswhiles hard enough pressed. I min' o' Reuben lendin'her five shiUings tae tide her ower tiU Marget's moneycame in frae Drumsheugh Gardens; an' I min' fine o'twa Sabbaths when she cudna gang tae the kirkbecause her boots were dune. I wonner if Margethelps her ony the noo ? Ye never heard 'Leesbethsay?

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: and Margaret started for Drumsheugh Gardens, whitherHenry Gordon accompanied her; ever and anon lostin either wonder or boundless admiration, and littledreaming that these same scenes would one day meethis gaze under such widely different impressions.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Mrs. Blain's ill-humour showed no signs of dissipatinguntil toward noon, when the lowering clouds driftedaway. Mary started for Drumsheugh Gardens tocarry home some white-work she had been embroidering for Edith Buchanan. Henry was to lunch withhis uncle, so he need not be expected until evening;aud William Maxwell took the train for Glasgow, tovisit his parents, and also to deliver a small parcelwhich Tom Hinde had entrusted to his charge for asister in the Trongate shop.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: " Miss Blain is at Drumsheugh Gardens in charge ofthe Buchanan chUdren during the absence of theirmother in London ; but if it's anything urgent, wouldI do instead, Gardner ?"

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Poor Mrs. Blain was sorely perplexed. She knewthe young men would both be at Drumsheugh Gardens,but how was she to get the hasty message conveyed tothem ? Fancying old Mr. M'Chestney had had a" stroke " (as he was very feeble when Henry last lefthome), she determined to put on her bonnet and gloves,and hurry over with the missive herself.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: " I don t know that he will, but he does come in at tinies. It s Mr. Inch, from Drumsheugh Gardens, Miss Xelly, and he d be frightened to see you here, an me away. Will you please tell him, from me, that I m all right, only I ve got a cold, and I ll be out again to-morrow ?"
